physDesc.additions: Marginalia: in Richard Bull's hand: Gorhambury House

div.p:
I am happy to hear from you from any quarter of the Globe; but am made more happy to find that you have the satisfaction of finding that your situation has so well an
swered the purpose. I have thoughts of visiting town before this winter is past; perhaps next month & shall be much mortified not to meet with you there. have not you & the Ladies fortitude enough, contemnere "to despisefashion, & to be regular amindst the temptations of an irregular age? It is surely worthy the tryal especially when health is to be
the reward

A Letter of mine was probably in stratton-street when yours reached me. I must refer to that for an account of Moses's labors. Could this possibly refer to the undated no. 35? I w
ish I could flatter you with the hopes of having a volume in any reasonable time, but other work crosses us & occasions delays. I thank you much for your kind remembranc in the work of Holbein This is the first in a series of apparent references to what emerges, from the evidence of no. 75, to be a gift of a collection of Holbein drawings from Bull to Pennant, in at least two 'parts'. See nos. 46, 75. LINK TO BIOGRAPHIES: {Hans Holbein, the younger} [although this could also refer to his father, Hans Holbein the Elder, but I don't think so. Holbein the younger far more interesting to Bull as a British art collector] but it is really unnecessary. The hard weather has left us in the gentlest manner & as grain is reasonable, & there is a vast addition of manufacturores, our poor are tolerably well off. The known & unknown of this house present their best complims & wishes of the season to Miss Bulls

closer.salute:
& I remain with true regard
Dear Sir
Your obliged & affect
humble servt

postscript.p: Mazel is publishing a pretty work of scotch views for Mr Cordiner as appendages to my scotch tour.
